title: From itchy problem to smart solutions
content: Mosquitoes are more than just a summer nuisance; they pose a significant global health challenge, killing over 700,000 people every year. Mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue , Zika , and chikungunya were once considered distant threats, but climate change and rapid urbanisation are enabling mosquitoes to spread to new areas, including parts of Europe. A challenge of this scale requires a global, unified response rather than just local efforts. To answer this threat, the COST Action Inv...

title: COST in review 2025
content: As we wrap up our 2025 activities, this is the time to look back and see all this year’s achievements, filled with networking, events, training, and new opportunities for the COST Action community. Our 316 running COST Actions created 575,065 connections between Action participants. Increases in the use of COST Action networking tools were seen in training schools, and in the use of the Conference Grants for Young Researchers and Innovators. title: Science communication best practice: SlowMemo
content: Self-guided museum activities to engage with our past and present Slow memory is an emergent concept that offers a new angle to reflect on how societies and individuals remember the pasts that meaningfully affects their present and future. It begins from the premise that we are familiar with commemorating sudden or extreme events such as wars, atrocities, or catastrophes but we are less certain about how to deal with slow-moving transformations that may be just as impactful. title: Long read: traces that connect us
content: Traces that connect us COST Action TRACTS COST LONG READS   Across Europe and beyond, traces of the past, such as artefacts, memories and landscape scars, tell stories about who we are and how we live. Until recently, however, there was no single field that brought together the scientists, artists, curators and activists who study these traces. title: Science communication best practice: PoTaRCh
content: Poetry to explore writing from the woods Hidden in the wood: potash, charcoal, resin, tar. Treasures forgotten. If you don’t recognise it, that’s a haiku, a type of short form poetry that originates from Japan.
